Metadata.siteDescription: Tracking Montreal's municipal performance with the city's own open data. Permits, contracts, 311 requests, and campaign promises.

Footer.disclaimer: This is an independent project and is not affiliated with the City of Montreal.

ErrorPage.title: Something went wrong
ErrorPage.description: The data could not be loaded. Please try again.

HomePage.heroSubtitle: MontréalScore connects campaign promises to real outcomes — tracking permit delays, contract spending, 311 response times, and political commitments using the City's own open data. No opinions. No party affiliation. Just the numbers.
HomePage.volunteerBody: The contracts page tracks billions in municipal spending, but verifying sole-source justifications, finding related news coverage, and cross-referencing supplier data takes time. The promise tracker also needs help — monitoring council decisions, flagging progress on commitments, and sourcing updates from local media. If you're a journalist, researcher, data analyst, or engaged citizen — we'd love your help.
HomePage.ctaTitle: No opinions. No party affiliation. Just the data.
HomePage.ctaBody: All data comes from the City of Montreal's open data portal and public reporting. Updated regularly. MontréalScore connects promises to outcomes — so you can hold your government accountable.

metadata.title: Construction Permits — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking construction permit processing times by borough in Montreal.

PermitsPage.title: Housing Permits
PermitsPage.subtitle: Processing times for housing permits (projects adding dwelling units) vs the {target}-day target (Mayor Martinez Ferrada's promise). The previous target was {previousTarget} days.
PermitsPage.housingNote: Housing permits = projects adding dwelling units (nb_logements > 0). The 90-day target applies to these permits. Tree cutting, pool, fence, and snow permits are excluded.
PermitsPage.noHousingData: No housing permit data available for this year. Try selecting a previous year.
PermitsPage.chartFootnote: Green dashed line = {target}-day target. Colors reflect the borough's grade. Housing permits only (projects adding dwelling units).
PermitsPage.methodologyText: This page shows housing permits only — projects that add dwelling units (nb_logements > 0 in the dataset). The 90-day processing target applies to these residential projects, not to tree cutting, pool, fence, or snow permits. Processing times are calculated from the date_debut (application date) and date_emission (issuance date) fields. The median is used instead of the average to reduce the impact of outliers. Data is updated weekly by the City.

metadata.title: About — MontréalScore
metadata.description: How MontréalScore works, what it tracks, and how you can contribute.

AboutPage.title: About MontréalScore
AboutPage.intro: MontréalScore is a free, open-source accountability tool that tracks the performance of Montreal's municipal government using the City's own open data and public reporting.
AboutPage.intro2: We track campaign promises, construction permit processing times, municipal contract spending, and 311 service request volumes — giving Montrealers a clear, fact-based picture of how their city is being run.
AboutPage.whatPromisesDetail: Every major campaign commitment made by Mayor Soraya Martinez Ferrada and Ensemble Montréal, tracked from announcement to delivery. Each promise is rated (completed, in progress, partially met, or broken) with sourced updates from local news coverage.
AboutPage.whatPermitsDetail: Borough-by-borough analysis of permit processing times. The mayor promised a 90-day turnaround — we track how each borough actually performs, with median wait times and year-over-year trends.
AboutPage.whatContractsDetail: Every city contract over $2,000 — who gets them, how much they're worth, and whether spending patterns raise questions. Includes procurement threshold analysis and supplier concentration data.
AboutPage.what311Detail: Volume, resolution rates, and average response times for citizen requests across all boroughs. Over 350,000 requests per year — from potholes to property taxes.
AboutPage.whyBody: Politicians make promises. Open data exists. But no one was connecting the two. The median permit processing time exceeds 200 days in some boroughs despite a 90-day target. Campaign commitments are announced at press conferences and then forgotten. Contract data is published but never analyzed in context.
AboutPage.whyBody2: MontréalScore connects the dots. No opinions. No party affiliation. Just the data, the sources, and the results.
AboutPage.dataSourcesIntro: All quantitative data comes from <link>Montreal's open data portal</link>. Promise tracking uses public news reporting. Datasets include:
AboutPage.dataPromisesDetail: manually tracked with sourced updates from La Presse, Le Devoir, CBC, Journal Métro, and city publications
AboutPage.data311Detail: aggregate volumes and resolution data from the city's 311 request system, updated daily
AboutPage.methodologyIntro: All analyses are built from publicly available data with no editorializing. Key approaches:
AboutPage.methodologyPermits: Permits: We calculate median processing times and on-time rates per borough, compared against the city's stated 90-day target.
AboutPage.methodologyContracts: Contracts: We aggregate spending across all four approval bodies, normalize supplier names, filter intergovernmental transfers, and flag patterns like sole-sourcing, threshold clustering, and spending concentration.
AboutPage.methodology311: 311: We query aggregate volumes, resolution rates, and response times from the city's CKAN API — no individual request data is downloaded.
AboutPage.methodologyPromises: Promises: Each commitment is rated based on publicly verifiable evidence — official announcements, budget documents, news coverage, and city data. Statuses are updated as new information becomes available.
AboutPage.contributeBody: MontréalScore is only as good as its sources. If you have information about a campaign promise, a news article we missed, or a correction — we want to hear from you.
AboutPage.contributeTip: Spotted progress (or broken promises) that we haven't tracked yet?
AboutPage.contributeSource: Have a news article, council meeting clip, or budget document to share?
AboutPage.contributeCorrection: Found an error in our data or analysis?
AboutPage.contributeHow: Send tips and corrections to <email>me@ashwater.ca</email>. All submissions are verified before publication.
AboutPage.contactBody: MontréalScore is built by <ashwater>Ashwater</ashwater>, an independent Montreal-based studio. For inquiries, tips, or media requests: <email>me@ashwater.ca</email>.

metadata.title: Municipal Contracts — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking municipal contracts for the City of Montreal — suppliers, departments, and amounts.

ContractsPage.title: Municipal Contracts
ContractsPage.subtitle: Procurement contracts approved by city council, executive committee, borough councils, and civil servants. Intergovernmental transfers are excluded.
ContractsPage.concentrationSubtitle: What share of municipal spending goes to the largest suppliers?
ContractsPage.concentrationDetail: of spending goes to the top {count} suppliers
ContractsPage.distributionSubtitle: Number of contracts by value range. Highlighted bars border Quebec procurement thresholds.
ContractsPage.distributionFootnote: Highlighted bars = ranges adjacent to $25K (no formal process) and $139K (mandatory public tender, 2026-2027 threshold) thresholds.
ContractsPage.thresholdSubtitle: In Quebec, contracts under $25K require no formal process. Above the public tender threshold, a public call for tenders is mandatory. The threshold has changed over time ($100K in 2017, $101.1K in 2019, $105.7K in 2022, $121.2K in late 2022, $133.8K in 2024, $139K in 2026). The analysis below applies the threshold in effect at each contract's approval date.
ContractsPage.thresholdMethodology: Comparison uses a symmetric value band above the threshold as baseline. The threshold applied matches the one in effect at each contract's approval date. A ratio significantly above 1 may indicate contract splitting. Sources: <lcv>art. 573.3.1.2, Loi sur les cités et villes</lcv> ($25K threshold); <mamh>MAMH — Conformité des contrats municipaux</mamh> (public tender thresholds, adjusted biennially via Muni-Express).
ContractsPage.soleSourceSubtitle: Contracts awarded without competitive bidding, as identified in council/committee descriptions. Sole-source contracts are legal under Quebec law for specific situations (urgency, sole supplier, security) but their growth is a key transparency indicator.
ContractsPage.soleSourceNone: No sole-source contracts identified in this period. Sole-source awards are identified from council/committee decision descriptions, which are not available for contracts under delegated authority (civil servants).
ContractsPage.yearlyTrendSubtitle: How contract spending breaks down by which body approves: civil servants (delegated authority, under $25K–$139K), borough councils, executive committee, city council, or agglomeration council. Larger contracts require higher-level approval.
ContractsPage.notableFindingsSubtitle: Patterns and outliers in the contract data that warrant further investigation. These are observations, not accusations — each may have a legitimate explanation.
ContractsPage.findingSoleSourceGrowthTitle: Sole-source spending grew 8.6x in a decade
ContractsPage.findingSoleSourceGrowthBody: Sole-source contract value went from $48M in 2015 to $414M in 2025. While some of this reflects larger infrastructure projects with legitimate sole-supplier justifications, the trend significantly outpaces inflation and overall budget growth.
ContractsPage.findingDurokingBody: The city's datasets record Duroking Construction under 14 different spellings (with/without Quebec Inc number, different punctuation, different separators). Without normalization, this major supplier appears fragmented across the top-supplier rankings — understating its true market share. We identified and merged similar patterns for 30+ suppliers.
ContractsPage.findingSingleBidderBody: Beyond sole-source contracts, some publicly tendered contracts attracted only a single bidder (soumissionnaire unique). From 2015–2025, 319 such contracts totalled $480M. While the process is formally competitive, a single bidder means no price competition occurred.
ContractsPage.normalizationSubtitle: The city's five contract datasets contain thousands of supplier name variants — typos, casing differences, trailing punctuation, and Quebec Inc numbers appended in different formats. Without normalization, the same company appears as multiple entries, understating true concentration.
ContractsPage.normalizationExplanation: We maintain a curated list of known variants for the largest suppliers. Names that don't match a known variant are standardized by normalizing casing and stripping trailing commas. Below are examples of the mergings applied.
ContractsPage.splitSubtitle: Suppliers with multiple contracts in the $15K–$25K range dated close together. Under Quebec law, contracts below $25K require no formal process — splitting a larger contract into smaller ones to avoid oversight is prohibited (art. 573.3.0.2 LCV). Flagged: 3+ contracts within 90 days, or 2 contracts totaling over $25K within 60 days.
ContractsPage.splitNone: No suspicious contract splitting patterns detected in this period.
ContractsPage.splitMethodology: This analysis identifies suppliers with clusters of contracts in the $15K–$24,999 range. A cluster is flagged when 3+ contracts fall within 90 days, or 2 contracts totaling over $25K fall within 60 days. These patterns may have legitimate explanations (recurring maintenance, phased work). The list is sorted by combined cluster value.
ContractsPage.searchDateHint: Results are filtered by the date range selected above.
ContractsPage.searchPlaceholder: Search by supplier, department, keyword, or amount (e.g. 50k, >100000, $25k-50k)…
ContractsPage.loyaltySubtitle: Which departments concentrate their contract spending with a single supplier? The percentage shown is the supplier's share of that department's total contract value in the selected period (not the department's overall budget). Pairs exceeding 50% may indicate limited competition or sole-supplier dependence.
ContractsPage.loyaltyNone: No significant department-supplier concentration found in this period.
ContractsPage.growthSubtitle: The selected date range is split at its midpoint. For each supplier with over $100K in both halves, we compare total contract value in the early period vs the late period. A supplier going from $1M to $3M shows +200% growth. Large jumps may reflect new long-term contracts, expanded scope, or shifting procurement patterns.
ContractsPage.growthNone: Not enough data to compute growth trajectories. This analysis requires suppliers with over $100K in both halves of the period — try selecting a wider date range (e.g. 5+ years).
ContractsPage.monthlySubtitle: Monthly distribution of contract approvals across the selected period. The busiest month is highlighted.
ContractsPage.monthlyNone: No monthly data available for this period.
ContractsPage.roundNumberSubtitle: Contracts at exact round amounts just below procurement thresholds ($25K for informal process, and public tender thresholds that changed over time). Suspicious clustering of round numbers just below a threshold may suggest deliberate pricing to avoid oversight. Each threshold is applied only to contracts from its effective period.
ContractsPage.roundNumberComparison: For comparison: {count} contracts in the equivalent band just above the threshold.
ContractsPage.roundNumberNone: No round-number clustering detected in this period.
ContractsPage.methodologyText: Data comes from five City of Montreal open datasets: contracts approved by city council, the agglomeration council, the executive committee, and borough councils, plus contracts awarded under delegated authority by civil servants. Intergovernmental transfers (ARTM, STM, CMM, etc.) and union/pension contributions are excluded to focus on actual procurement. Supplier names are normalized to merge known variants (e.g. 14 spellings of "Duroking Construction"). Sole-source contracts are identified by text matching "gré à gré" in council/committee decision descriptions — some records may contain the phrase in a sub-clause rather than as the primary award type. Amounts are in Canadian dollars.

metadata.title: Campaign Promises — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking Mayor Martinez Ferrada's campaign promises for Montreal.

PromisesPage.title: Campaign Promise Tracker
PromisesPage.subtitle: Tracking Mayor Soraya Martinez Ferrada's campaign commitments against real-world outcomes.
PromisesPage.platformCommitmentsSubtitle: Commitments from Ensemble Montréal's 2025 campaign platform, organized by theme. These promises cover the entire city.
PromisesPage.boroughCommitmentsSubtitle: Local commitments made by Ensemble Montréal candidates in each borough. Anjou and LaSalle ran under independent allied parties and are not included.
PromisesPage.methodologyText: Promises are extracted from the Ensemble Montréal 2025 campaign platform. Statuses are updated manually based on news reports, council decisions, and official announcements. The first 100 days countdown starts from the inauguration date (November 10, 2025).

metadata.title: Volunteer — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Help track Montreal's campaign promises. Many are qualitative and need citizen first-hand experience to verify.

VolunteerPage.title: Help Us Track Montreal's Promises
VolunteerPage.heroSubtitle: Many campaign promises are qualitative — "shorter permit delays", "better snow removal", "improved services" — and can't be tracked through news or open data alone. We need citizens with first-hand experience to help verify them.
VolunteerPage.problemText: Many of the campaign promises we track are qualitative commitments that require local knowledge to verify. Things like "ensure harmonious cohabitation with residents" or "reduce bureaucratic complexity" don't show up in datasets — only people who interact with the city daily can tell us if these promises are being kept.
VolunteerPage.howIntro: If you live in Montreal, you already have the data we need. Here's what we're looking for:
VolunteerPage.howPermitsDetail: Applied for a permit recently? Was the process faster, slower, or the same as before?
VolunteerPage.howServicesDetail: Called 311? Visited a borough office? Was it accessible, responsive, helpful?
VolunteerPage.howNeighbourhoodDetail: Cleanliness, safety, snow removal, road conditions — what's actually changed on the ground?
VolunteerPage.howCouncilDetail: Attending local borough or city council meetings? Let us know about decisions related to campaign promises.
VolunteerPage.ctaText: Have observations, evidence, or corrections about any of these promises? Send us your input:
VolunteerPage.ctaNote: All submissions are reviewed before publication. We protect source anonymity.

metadata.title: 311 Service Requests — MontréalScore
metadata.description: Tracking 311 service request volume, response times, and resolution rates by borough in Montreal.

ServiceRequestsPage.title: 311 Service Requests
ServiceRequestsPage.subtitle: Citizen requests, complaints, and information inquiries submitted to the City via the 311 system, email, and Bureau Accès Montréal offices. Data since 2022, updated daily.
ServiceRequestsPage.noData: 311 data is not yet available. Please check back later.
ServiceRequestsPage.boroughSubtitle: Service request volume and resolution rates by borough. Resolution rate = percentage of requests with "Terminée" (completed) status. Internal administrative units (311 call center, corporate services) are excluded.
ServiceRequestsPage.categorySubtitle: The 20 most common service request categories for the selected year. Categories are defined by the city and vary somewhat between boroughs.
ServiceRequestsPage.channelSubtitle: How citizens reach 311. Phone (311 hotline) handles the majority of requests.
ServiceRequestsPage.statusSubtitle: Final status of service requests for the selected year.
ServiceRequestsPage.potholeSubtitle: Pothole (nid-de-poule) repair requests — one of the most common 311 categories. Resolution rate and response time for the selected year.
ServiceRequestsPage.potholeCaveat: "Resolution" reflects the city's administrative closure rate — requests marked "Terminée" in the 311 system. This does not confirm the pothole was physically repaired. The 311 system tracks intake and routing, not work completion. Processes vary by borough: some mark requests closed when transferring to internal work-order systems. The Auditor General flagged this data gap in 2018.
ServiceRequestsPage.potholeNoData: No pothole data available for this year.
ServiceRequestsPage.trendSubtitle: Monthly request volume across all natures (requests, complaints, information, comments).
ServiceRequestsPage.methodologyText: Data comes from the City of Montreal's 311 open dataset ("Demandes de services citoyennes"). The dataset covers all citizen requests submitted via phone (311), email, and Bureau Accès Montréal offices. Geographic coordinates are obfuscated for privacy. Information requests (general inquiries answered immediately) lack borough assignment and unique IDs. Response time is calculated as the difference between the creation date and last status date for completed requests. Categories may vary between boroughs due to local configurations.
